LANYON STARS FOR JAYS
Hopkins Gains Five Point Lead
in First Half, but Weakens

and

i;t.00
1.20

'Mt

Outplayed during a hectic second
half, Hopkins lost a hard-fought
game to New York University, 2623, at Carlin's last night. N. Y. U.
came back strong in the'secondhalf,
overcoming a five point lead in the
last few minutes of play. With
six minutes to go and. the score
18-16 in favor of Hopkins, Dynan
made a field goal and Werner sank
a foul to give the New Yorkers the
lead for the, first time since the
Opening whistle. Kaufman put a
field goal in to give the Jays a one
Point advantage, but Roberts then
sank a long one and Newblatt followed up with another from the
floor. Leibensperger revived Hopkins' hopes with a double-decker,
but Dynan countered with another.
Lang and Holdman both sank fouls,
and the game ended shortly after
Haldman's dropped through the netting. Lanyan played consistently
good ball throughout the game.

HOMEWOOD, BALTIMORE, MD., JANUARY 13, 1928

NO ACTION YET ONLIBRARY WINDOWS
Up to the present time no
action has been taken on the
erection of stained-glass windows for the library. The
only information which Dr.
French has upon them is that
a committee from the Board
of Trustees has been formed
to see the Advising Architects.
The- report from this committee will go to the.Trustees,
who, then, will act as the committee directs. When this report is to be made is unknown.
The plan, as it is understood, is to have tall, stainedglass windows in the circular
alcove of the library.

Staff Begins Work
on 1928 Yearbook
Work on the editorial make-up
of the 1928 Hullabaloo began last
Monday evening at a joint meeting of the staff and candidates,
which was held in the office of the
Black and Blue Jay. About twenty
men attended.
Editor-in-chief Donald White
addressed the new men and then
assigned the write-ups of the graduating students, activities, etc. Material is supposed to be in the week
following examinations, thus giving
the staff ample time to arrange and
correct copy.

PRESIDENT PLANS
RETIREMENT IN '29

"Y's" Plans for Structure Near
Gilman Hall Complete

Dr. Goodnow Asks to Be Relieved
on or Before July 1

CAMPAIGN TO BEGIN SOON

NO DEFINITE SUCCESSOR

Dr. French, Chairman of Board,
Supervising Work'

Mr. Willard Reads Letter at
Committee Meeting

Within the next few weeks the
Johns Hopkins Y. M. C. A. will
start a drive to raise $165,000 for
a new "Y" and Student Activities'
building. "It is our purpose to
bring Levering Hall to Homewood,"
said Dr. John C. French, Chairman
of the Board of Managers of the
Hopkins Y. M. C. A., in commenting on the proposed new "Y" building. Old Levering Hall was the
Johns Hopkins Y. M. C. A. building of the nineties and the early
nineteen hundreds. "Although the
new Levering Hall is a 'Y' enterprise," continued Dr. French, "it is
designed to serve all the students
on the campus and will be so administered as to contribute to their welfare in every possible way."

"I am seventy years old and it
is time to go on the shelf," said Dr.
Frank Johnson Goodnow, President
of this University, in discussing the
announcement of his resignation
made to the executive committee of
the Board of Trustees at its meeting last Monday night. President
Goodnow's resignation will not go
into effect before July 1, 1929, however, unless a successor is found
who can take his place at an earlier
date.

New Site

The site for Levering Hall will
be south of Gilman Hall, directly
opposite the now unused road
which leads to the Barn. It was
originally the desire of the Association to have the new structure facing the bowl or near the present
position of the Barn. This proved
impracticable, and what is in every
respect a more central and convenient place directly south of Gilman
Hall was chosen.
Preliminary plans for Levering
Hall have been drawn up by the
architectural firm of Palmer, Willis
and Lamdin and have been approved by the Y. M. C. A., the advisory architects to the University,
and the Trustees of the University.
A detailed account of the plan of
the new building is being written
by Mr. Palmer, who is an alumnus
of Johns Hopkins, and will appear
in the next issue of the NEWS-LETTER. This will supplement the following briefer account which was
given by Dr. French.

DR. FRANK J. GOODNOW,
President of Johns Hopkins
Since 1914

JUNIOR DEBATING
TEAM SELECTED
Brown, Ness, Driver, Littlefield
Chosen to Represent Class
Stewart Brown, Philip Ness, William Driver and John Littlefield
were chosen by the Debating Council to form the junior debating team.
The tryouts, which were held last
Tuesday, were unusually good, according to Dr. Earle Uhler, faculty
adviser of the council, who said that
the material on hand was the best
he had ever seen to represent any
class.

To Act February 23

Action on Dr. Goodnow's letter
will be taken at the meeting of the
full Board of Trustees to be held on
February 23. In the meantime a
special committee has been appointed by the executive committee
of the Board of Trustees to consider Dr. Goodnow's resignation
and a possible successor for him
in 1929. The committee consists
of the following members:
Hon. Newton D. Baker, former
U. S. Secretary of War, a prominent Hopkins alumnus; C. P. Howland, B. H. Griswold and Frederick
W. Wood, all members of the
Board of Trustees; and Daniel Willard, president of the Board, a
member ex officio. The committee
will make its report to the Board
of Trustees on February 23.

Regardless of the time-worn tradition which allows theatrical
"news" to grow dustier and dustier
while awaiting belated exposition
as a Black and Blue Jay space-filler,
we have decided to fulfill the demands of a more yawning if no
more popular column by extenuated
reference to Baltimore's dramatic
entertainment. (The above requires
re - reading; the writer thinks he
knows what he means. Why must
undergraduates invariably employ
a bombastic and unnatural style for
the discussion of out-and-out tripe?)
Next to Beatrice Lillie, we like
"Yours Truly." Insidious influence
of the B. V. D. advertisement. The
same irrestible Beatrice who sang
"The March of the Seasons,"
"Mouse, Mouse," and "Nicodemus"
chirps triumphantly, "But I don't
care; I'm going on the stage."
A great many critics who ought
to know have given the only Lillie
in the field a great deal of credit,
and have most unmercifully roasted
the play. It was weighed in the
balance, we presume, and found
wanton. (Blame Mr. Riddell, in
"Vanity Fair," who also allows that
James Branch Cabell knows his
"grosseries."
"A Spot on the Sun." Why?
No, no, not the play, the title? Such
ignorance! . . . Well, what does
it mean? Something synonymous
to "a stench in the nostrils of God ?"
Extremely modest self-estimation
on the part of the author, according to the production's New York
flop. But we disagree,; it had no
right to flop. The dialogues of the
stout baroness or countess or something with her gigolo were as revolting as any lines in "The Shanghai
Gesture," which is saying plenty.

And Helen Chandler, as the
youthful prophetess of the new
generation, was rather charming
despite the Peter Pan voice. Which
reminds us, for no apparent reason,
of the sad case of Michael Strange,
that buxom lassie whose managers
lost forty-five thousand on her contralto production of L'Aiglon.
Our usher friend, the rather anaemic, but oh, so kindly damsel in the
pit at the Auditorium, demanded
why the hell, when we staggered in
for the first act of the Rostand massacre. After ten minutes we agreed
with the usher.
How long before the Little Theatre will degenerate to the level of
the Aurora and the Rialto? We
consider it a question of time, for
the very simple reason that there
aren't very many good movies.
"Tartuffe," with the incomparable
Emil Jannings—oh, by the way—
does one Anglicise, or should you
be very Guilford and call it "Yanninks ?" Seriously, now? Anyhow, the gent has gone Hollywood
now; there will be no more "Tartuffe's." "Stark Love" was the accidental result of a cameraman's
peripatetic instincts. That glorious animal, Helen Mundy, packs
more of Miss Glynn's intangible
"That" than La Garbage herself,
but she will never get a chance at
"Anna Karenina" or anything else.
As for the quaint little psychological film, with the red-hot title—
well, we know our symbols.
We wished to discuss the project
with Drs. Shanks and Uhler, who
attended the same private (oh,
very) performance as ourselves.
-an't some energetic reporter scrape
up an interview?
A. C. W.

START BUILDING DRIVE

PRESIDENT GOODNOW'S RESIGNATION
The retirement of President Goodnow will come at a time when
his theories concerning University education are just in the infancy of their practical application. Having given the initial
impetus to the plan of beginning "graduate work" at the end of
the *first two years of college, Dr. Goodnow will be able to watch
its growth from the point of view of the interested spectator,
watching, as it were, some one else rear his favorite child.
The local papers have been filled this week with eulogies of
Dr. Goodnow's administration at Johns Hopkins. They have
.told, in glowing panegyric, of the advancement of the University
within the past ten years. It is enough for us to say, therefore,
in these few words, that we hope that the fourth president of
Johns Hopkins University will carry aloft her standards as gloriously as the third has done.

LEVERING HALL
Within the next few weeks the Y. M. C. A. will begin its drive
to secure the $165,000 necessary for the erection of the proposed
Levering Hall, the status of which has been a matter'of considerable; conjecture and discussion on the campus. It has been referred to as a Student Activities Building, a Y. M. C. A. Building
and simply as a Students' Building. Inasmuch as it is quite
probable that the students of the University will be asked to
contribute to the fund, we feel that the status of the building
should be clearly defined to the student body.
First of all, it should _be understood that Levering Hall will
not be a Student Activities Building. According to the Y. M. C. A.
authorities, any student activity which desires to use any of the
•.various meeting rooms will always be extended this privilege,
although no space will be specifically allocated to any individual
body. The activities will retain their offices in the Barn, which
will be devoted to their use until the activities themselves should
go out of existence.
The new building will assume the nature of a clubhouse, a
purpose for which the Barn is so patently inadequate. It will
be a comfortable, attractive place where the students may lounge
during their lunch hour or other free time. And the most tangible feature of Levering Hall will be a cafeteria, where students
and faculty can enjoy eating their meals.
Of course, the building will nominally belong to the Y. M. C. A.
And although we believe that the more feasible plan would be
.to have the building under the direct control of the University,
the latter's absolute lack of funds for the purpose makes the
scheme impossible. There is every reason to believe, however,
that the Y. M. C. A. will administer Levering Hall wisely and
unselfishly. It is the NEWS-LETTER'S sincere hope that the
$165,000 be raised in time for the class of 1929 to reap the
benefits.
The NEWS-LETTER regrets to announce the resignation of
Donald Hiss as Assistant Managing Editor. The NEWS-LETTER
takes great pleasure in announcing the election of George E.
Banks, Jr., as Assistant Managing Editor.

All letters intended for publication must be concise, written
in ink, on one side of the paper
only.
No attention will be paid to
anonymous letters, but names
signed as an evidence of good
faith will not be printed if request is made that they be omitted.
The publication of a letter is
not to be taken as an endorsement of its views by "The NewsLetter" which invites the freest
discussion of all matters of general interest.

A SUGGESTION
To the Editor of the NEWS-LETTER:
Dear Sir:
With the approach of mid-years,
students taking courses in both the
College of Arts and Sciences and
the Teachers' College find them- selves in a serious predicament in
many cases.
The

examination

schedule as

Posted includes all the undergraduate courses, but none of those in
the Teachers' College. The time
of these examinations is optional
With the various professors.
In many cases these courses are
being assigned examination periods
Which conflict with the already
Posted lists. Perhaps the conflict
is not definitely in the same hours,

THE JOHNS HOPKINS NEWS-LETTER, JANUARY 13, 1928

4

PRESIDENT GOODNOW
TO RETIRE IN 1929
Mr. Willard Read Announcement
at Committee Meeting Last
Monday
(Continued from page 1, column 5)

"I am going to have some fun."
He furthermore stated that he will
not return to China; his plans for
traveling have not been formulated,
and cannot be made until he knows
at what date he will be relieved by
his successor. As for writing,
President Goodnow does not apparently intend to publish any books
after his retirement.
That Dr. Goodnow will not continue to be connected with the University in any capacity, except possibly that of President Emeritus, is
an established fact. Dr. Goodnow's
predecessor, the late Ira Remsen,
held that office for fourteen years
after his retirement in 1913.
In his letter to Mr. Willard Dr.
Goodnow asked that he be relieved
on or before July 1, 1929, or as
soon as a successor can be secured.
The text of the letter is as follows:
Daniel Willard, Esq.,
President of the Board of
Trustees, the Johns
Hopkins University.
My Dear Mr. Willard—On
January 18, 1929, I shall, if
I live, have attained the age
of 70. I think, in view of
this fact, I should, not later
than July 1, 1929, be relieved
of my duties as president of
the university.
I am therefore handing to
you in this fetter my resignation, to go into effect not later
than July 1, 1929, in order that
you and the trustees may have
ample time in which to select
my successor. Inasmuch as
you may be able to find some
one prior to the date mentioned whom you might wish
to call immediately, will you
please regard this letter as requesting you to accept my
resignation at any time prior
to July 1, 1929, which might
seem to you desirable.
I am handing you my resignation with great regret and
only because it seems to me
that the time has come for me
to do so. My life at the university has been most pleasant
and my relations with the
board could not have been
more agreeable than they have
been.
My good wishes will always
go out to the university and I
shall always look with interest
upon the progress which I am
certain it will make.
I am with the highest personal regards to you and the
other members of the board,
Yours, most sincerely,
FRANK J. GOODNOW.
Mr. Willard, Dean Ames and Dr.
Goodnow, himself, do not know at
present who the latter's successor
will be. It is expected that the
matter will be turned over to a committee of the Board of Trustees on
February 23. The committee will
hold sessions, travel, meet again and
discuss plans, and consume a considerable amount of time before any
decision is reached. It is almost
certain that by next October no selection will yet have been made.
Blow to University

President Goodnow's resignation,
long expected though it may have
been, fills his University associates
with chagrin. Mr. Willard said
Wednesday:
"I regret exceedingly that Dr.
Goodnow considers it expedient to
retire from the Presidency of Johns
Hopkins."

DR. GOODNOW HAS ACHIEVED MUCH
BOTH AT HOPKINS AND ELSEWHERE
Since Dr. Frank J. Goodnow became President of Johns Hopkins
on October 1, 1914, this University
has taken many important forward
steps. Just a year after President
Goodnow's assumption of his duties, the University moved to its
present location at Homewood—a
change which opened many opportunities to students who had not had
sufficient room for their work or
could not before be accommodated
at all.
During the years of stress attendant upon the World War, it was
under Dr. Goodnow's leadership
that the University's activities were
adapted to the necessities of wartime. Following the Armistice the
University experienced the most
rapid growth in its history.
Dormitory and Remsen Hall

New plans were set on foot, and
the years 1923 and 1924 witnessed
the completion of the Alumni Memorial Dormitory and of Remsen
Hall, the first buildings erected
since the transfer to Homewood.
Meanwhile Dr. Goodnow supervised the constant improvement of
the faculty and the continued
growth of the Medical School.
But the greatest achievements of
President Goodnow's term have
been the New, Plan and the HalfCentury CommemOration. To mention both in the same breath is perhaps to slight the former. It was
the President's idea to bring Johns
Hopkins back to the unrivaled reputation as an institution for research
and for the discovery of new truth
which it had held under Dr. Gilman. During the period of rapid

One cannot consider Dr. Goodnow's achievements here without
turning to his record before the
Trustees asked him to become the
head of the University. He took
the degrees of Bachelor and Master
of Arts at Amherst in 1879 and
1887, respectively; he studied also
at Columbia University, where he
teceived the LL.B degree; at the
Ecoles Libres des Sciences Politiques, in Paris, and at the University of Berlin. At Columbia, also,
he held successively the positions
of instructor and lecturer, adjutant
professor and professor of administrative law; in 1903 he was appointed Eaton Professor of Administrative law and municipal science;
during 1906-07 Dr. Goodnow was
acting dean of political science.
Legal Adviser to Chinese

Dr. Goodnow came into still
greater prominence, however, as
legal adviser to the Chinese Government, March 13, 1913-14. From
this post he came to Baltimore to
take over his duties as President.
He is still a member of the China
Medical Board (Rockefeller Foundation), and a fellow of the American Academy of Arts and Sciences.
President Goodnow has received
LL.D degrees from Amherst, Columbia, Harvard, Brown and
Princeton.

INTERCOLLEGIATE
NEWS
A sweeping athletic reorganization is at present under way at
Syracuse University. Many reforms have been adopted in an attempt to encourage as many students as possible to participate in
some form of athletic activity or
sporting endeavor, and to incidentally decrease the past expenses and
losses which the athletic association
has experienced in past years. Boxing, wrestling, fencing, tennis,
hockey, golf, soccer and rifle are
the sports which have been dropped
from the roster. Football, basketball, rowing, cross-country, lacrosse,
swimming and water polo are the
only activities which have been considered as worthy of retention. This
Plan was originally intended to have
gone into effect at the beginning of
this scholastic year but, because
of a definite outburst of sentiment
among the student body, the plan
was placed under reconsideration
by the athletic council, who recently
repassed it.
As a fact which may be-of interest to sport followers and especially
grid enthusiasts, it has been computed that out of the seventy-one
football captains who have been
selected to head their teams for next
year, forty-five, or over two-thirds
of the total, are linesmen,' while
only the remaining twenty-six are
backfield players. The days when
it was. customary for the quarterback to be the leader appear to have
vanished. Four colleges, Vermont,
Vebarska, Indiana and Iowa, State,
have dual captaincies.
We are informed by an exchange
that Harvard University is considering doing away with all initiations
on the grounds that they are too
childish and are out _of keeping with
the dignity of the institution.
It is rumored that in accordance
with the football reforms which
were proposed last year by the
President of Dartmouth University,
the University of Michigan will
Place two teams on tlre field next
season. An endeavor is being made
to schedule sixteen games, two to
be played on each Saturday of the
1928 campaign, at least one of
which will be played away from
home. This action is said to be a
result of the recent Big Ten conference, which passed a resolution permitting every member to card two
games each Saturday and excepting
them from the former home and
home scrimmage regulation.
* * * * *
Oxford and Cambridge universities are said to be planning a new
form of intercollegiate competition.
The two institutions are arranging
flying contests, which will take place
annually. Each school at present
has its own air squadron.
* * * * *
With the first season of the Air
College declared a success, the College of the City of New York has
opened the second semester over its
radio station. The lectures are
given by various members of the
faculty in an attempt to popularize
education.

6

JAY CAGERS BEAT
LOYOLA IN OPENER
Hopkins Team Surprises By
Winning, 26-23
Displaying a brand of basketball
and teamwork that could be appreciated only by a witness, the Johns
Hopkins cagers defeated the Loyola
College five in a hotly contested setto, by the score of 26-23.
In the game, which was not won
until the last thirty seconds of play,
Hopkins made a spectacular review
by outplaying the Irishmen in every
phase of the game. Loyola was
handicapped by the clever work of
Debuskey, Hopkins center, who outjumped his opponent in every start.
Incidentally, the Black and Blue
pivot man contributed more to the
final count than did any of his
mates, accounting for six tallies and
playing a wonderful floor game.
The rare work of the team as a
unit, however, is shown by the fact
that each man tallied at least three
points.
Dudley High Scorer

Captain Frank Dudley, high
scorer for the Green and Gray, was
undoubtedly the star of the contest.
In spite of his great effort, however, his charges were decisively
outplayed, especially during the first
period. At the half the Jays were
on the long end of a 16-9 score.
Although Loyola tied the score
near the close of the contest, Passerew's shot from the floor dashed
any hopes of the Irish for a victory.

CASUAL CONDUCT OF CAMPUS COUPLES
CAUSES COTILLON CLUB CONCERN
"Something for nothing" is usually mighty hard to get, and it has
been claimed by some bitter souls
that this is particularly true at Hopkins. But, at last a campus organization has blazed the trail; it has
declared that, for once, it will depart from its traditional policy and
give the boys a treat. The benevolent souls who originated this charitable idea are none other than the
members of the Johns Hopkins
Cotillon Club.
In an effort to correct the bad
habits of those naughty "collich"
boys who habitually straggle into
dances when they are nearly over,
this puritanical organization has decided to put a premium on punctuality. The first three couples to
arrive at the Cotillon Club dance tomorrow night may enter scot free.
Verily, "the early bird catches the
worm," but the club still maintains
that "it is better to come late than
not at all." Nevertheless, it is to
be noted that the club's charity ap
inscription, however, does not tell
all. Shuter was a pioneer in the
student activities at Johns Hopkins.
Back in 1897-98 the NEWS-LETTER
was first printed, and Shuter was
its first Business Manager.
Photo of Foch

plies only to couples and does not
extend to the stag line. Come early
and avoid the rush.
The dance will start promptly at
nine and it is expected that Goucher
girlies will benefit especially by the
new arrangement. A number of
ladies have recently been heard
complaining that these innocent
young ladies are kept out after
hours Saturday at Hopkins dances.
If the novel scheme works the parties may start early and end early.
Thus, the girls can get their much
needed beauty sleeps and a few
Hopkins escorts may be able to find
a solution to the problem of how to
do on the weeks' allowance.

Outplayed during a hectic second
half, Hopkins lost a hard-fought
game to New York University, 2623, at Carlin's last night. N. Y. U.
came back strong in the'secondhalf,
overcoming a five point lead in the
last few minutes of play. With
six minutes to go and. the score
18-16 in favor of Hopkins, Dynan
made a field goal and Werner sank
a foul to give the New Yorkers the
lead for the, first time since the
Opening whistle. Kaufman put a
field goal in to give the Jays a one
Point advantage, but Roberts then
sank a long one and Newblatt followed up with another from the
floor. Leibensperger revived Hopkins' hopes with a double-decker,
but Dynan countered with another.
Lang and Holdman both sank fouls,
and the game ended shortly after
Haldman's dropped through the netting. Lanyan played consistently
good ball throughout the game.

HOMEWOOD, BALTIMORE, MD., JANUARY 13, 1928

NO ACTION YET ONLIBRARY WINDOWS
Up to the present time no
action has been taken on the
erection of stained-glass windows for the library. The
only information which Dr.
French has upon them is that
a committee from the Board
of Trustees has been formed
to see the Advising Architects.
The- report from this committee will go to the.Trustees,
who, then, will act as the committee directs. When this report is to be made is unknown.
The plan, as it is understood, is to have tall, stainedglass windows in the circular
alcove of the library.

Staff Begins Work
on 1928 Yearbook
Work on the editorial make-up
of the 1928 Hullabaloo began last
Monday evening at a joint meeting of the staff and candidates,
which was held in the office of the
Black and Blue Jay. About twenty
men attended.
Editor-in-chief Donald White
addressed the new men and then
assigned the write-ups of the graduating students, activities, etc. Material is supposed to be in the week
following examinations, thus giving
the staff ample time to arrange and
correct copy.

TO OPEN STUDENT
BUILDING DRIVE

TO RETIRE

PRICE 5 CENTS

PRESIDENT PLANS
RETIREMENT IN '29

"Y's" Plans for Structure Near
Gilman Hall Complete

Dr. Goodnow Asks to Be Relieved
on or Before July 1

CAMPAIGN TO BEGIN SOON

NO DEFINITE SUCCESSOR

Dr. French, Chairman of Board,
Supervising Work'

Mr. Willard Reads Letter at
Committee Meeting

Within the next few weeks the
Johns Hopkins Y. M. C. A. will
start a drive to raise $165,000 for
a new "Y" and Student Activities'
building. "It is our purpose to
bring Levering Hall to Homewood,"
said Dr. John C. French, Chairman
of the Board of Managers of the
Hopkins Y. M. C. A., in commenting on the proposed new "Y" building. Old Levering Hall was the
Johns Hopkins Y. M. C. A. building of the nineties and the early
nineteen hundreds. "Although the
new Levering Hall is a 'Y' enterprise," continued Dr. French, "it is
designed to serve all the students
on the campus and will be so administered as to contribute to their welfare in every possible way."

"I am seventy years old and it
is time to go on the shelf," said Dr.
Frank Johnson Goodnow, President
of this University, in discussing the
announcement of his resignation
made to the executive committee of
the Board of Trustees at its meeting last Monday night. President
Goodnow's resignation will not go
into effect before July 1, 1929, however, unless a successor is found
who can take his place at an earlier
date.

New Site

The site for Levering Hall will
be south of Gilman Hall, directly
opposite the now unused road
which leads to the Barn. It was
originally the desire of the Association to have the new structure facing the bowl or near the present
position of the Barn. This proved
impracticable, and what is in every
respect a more central and convenient place directly south of Gilman
Hall was chosen.
Preliminary plans for Levering
Hall have been drawn up by the
architectural firm of Palmer, Willis
and Lamdin and have been approved by the Y. M. C. A., the advisory architects to the University,
and the Trustees of the University.
A detailed account of the plan of
the new building is being written
by Mr. Palmer, who is an alumnus
of Johns Hopkins, and will appear
in the next issue of the NEWS-LETTER. This will supplement the following briefer account which was
given by Dr. French.

DR. FRANK J. GOODNOW,
President of Johns Hopkins
Since 1914

JUNIOR DEBATING
TEAM SELECTED
Brown, Ness, Driver, Littlefield
Chosen to Represent Class
Stewart Brown, Philip Ness, William Driver and John Littlefield
were chosen by the Debating Council to form the junior debating team.
The tryouts, which were held last
Tuesday, were unusually good, according to Dr. Earle Uhler, faculty
adviser of the council, who said that
the material on hand was the best
he had ever seen to represent any
class.

To Act February 23

Action on Dr. Goodnow's letter
will be taken at the meeting of the
full Board of Trustees to be held on
February 23. In the meantime a
special committee has been appointed by the executive committee
of the Board of Trustees to consider Dr. Goodnow's resignation
and a possible successor for him
in 1929. The committee consists
of the following members:
Hon. Newton D. Baker, former
U. S. Secretary of War, a prominent Hopkins alumnus; C. P. Howland, B. H. Griswold and Frederick
W. Wood, all members of the
Board of Trustees; and Daniel Willard, president of the Board, a
member ex officio. The committee
will make its report to the Board
of Trustees on February 23.

Regardless of the time-worn tradition which allows theatrical
"news" to grow dustier and dustier
while awaiting belated exposition
as a Black and Blue Jay space-filler,
we have decided to fulfill the demands of a more yawning if no
more popular column by extenuated
reference to Baltimore's dramatic
entertainment. (The above requires
re - reading; the writer thinks he
knows what he means. Why must
undergraduates invariably employ
a bombastic and unnatural style for
the discussion of out-and-out tripe?)
Next to Beatrice Lillie, we like
"Yours Truly." Insidious influence
of the B. V. D. advertisement. The
same irrestible Beatrice who sang
"The March of the Seasons,"
"Mouse, Mouse," and "Nicodemus"
chirps triumphantly, "But I don't
care; I'm going on the stage."
A great many critics who ought
to know have given the only Lillie
in the field a great deal of credit,
and have most unmercifully roasted
the play. It was weighed in the
balance, we presume, and found
wanton. (Blame Mr. Riddell, in
"Vanity Fair," who also allows that
James Branch Cabell knows his
"grosseries."
"A Spot on the Sun." Why?
No, no, not the play, the title? Such
ignorance! . . . Well, what does
it mean? Something synonymous
to "a stench in the nostrils of God ?"
Extremely modest self-estimation
on the part of the author, according to the production's New York
flop. But we disagree,; it had no
right to flop. The dialogues of the
stout baroness or countess or something with her gigolo were as revolting as any lines in "The Shanghai
Gesture," which is saying plenty.

And Helen Chandler, as the
youthful prophetess of the new
generation, was rather charming
despite the Peter Pan voice. Which
reminds us, for no apparent reason,
of the sad case of Michael Strange,
that buxom lassie whose managers
lost forty-five thousand on her contralto production of L'Aiglon.
Our usher friend, the rather anaemic, but oh, so kindly damsel in the
pit at the Auditorium, demanded
why the hell, when we staggered in
for the first act of the Rostand massacre. After ten minutes we agreed
with the usher.
How long before the Little Theatre will degenerate to the level of
the Aurora and the Rialto? We
consider it a question of time, for
the very simple reason that there
aren't very many good movies.
"Tartuffe," with the incomparable
Emil Jannings—oh, by the way—
does one Anglicise, or should you
be very Guilford and call it "Yanninks ?" Seriously, now? Anyhow, the gent has gone Hollywood
now; there will be no more "Tartuffe's." "Stark Love" was the accidental result of a cameraman's
peripatetic instincts. That glorious animal, Helen Mundy, packs
more of Miss Glynn's intangible
"That" than La Garbage herself,
but she will never get a chance at
"Anna Karenina" or anything else.
As for the quaint little psychological film, with the red-hot title—
well, we know our symbols.
We wished to discuss the project
with Drs. Shanks and Uhler, who
attended the same private (oh,
very) performance as ourselves.
-an't some energetic reporter scrape
up an interview?
A. C. W.

PRESIDENT GOODNOW'S RESIGNATION
The retirement of President Goodnow will come at a time when
his theories concerning University education are just in the infancy of their practical application. Having given the initial
impetus to the plan of beginning "graduate work" at the end of
the *first two years of college, Dr. Goodnow will be able to watch
its growth from the point of view of the interested spectator,
watching, as it were, some one else rear his favorite child.
The local papers have been filled this week with eulogies of
Dr. Goodnow's administration at Johns Hopkins. They have
.told, in glowing panegyric, of the advancement of the University
within the past ten years. It is enough for us to say, therefore,
in these few words, that we hope that the fourth president of
Johns Hopkins University will carry aloft her standards as gloriously as the third has done.

LEVERING HALL
Within the next few weeks the Y. M. C. A. will begin its drive
to secure the $165,000 necessary for the erection of the proposed
Levering Hall, the status of which has been a matter'of considerable; conjecture and discussion on the campus. It has been referred to as a Student Activities Building, a Y. M. C. A. Building
and simply as a Students' Building. Inasmuch as it is quite
probable that the students of the University will be asked to
contribute to the fund, we feel that the status of the building
should be clearly defined to the student body.
First of all, it should _be understood that Levering Hall will
not be a Student Activities Building. According to the Y. M. C. A.
authorities, any student activity which desires to use any of the
•.various meeting rooms will always be extended this privilege,
although no space will be specifically allocated to any individual
body. The activities will retain their offices in the Barn, which
will be devoted to their use until the activities themselves should
go out of existence.
The new building will assume the nature of a clubhouse, a
purpose for which the Barn is so patently inadequate. It will
be a comfortable, attractive place where the students may lounge
during their lunch hour or other free time. And the most tangible feature of Levering Hall will be a cafeteria, where students
and faculty can enjoy eating their meals.
Of course, the building will nominally belong to the Y. M. C. A.
And although we believe that the more feasible plan would be
.to have the building under the direct control of the University,
the latter's absolute lack of funds for the purpose makes the
scheme impossible. There is every reason to believe, however,
that the Y. M. C. A. will administer Levering Hall wisely and
unselfishly. It is the NEWS-LETTER'S sincere hope that the
$165,000 be raised in time for the class of 1929 to reap the
benefits.
The NEWS-LETTER regrets to announce the resignation of
Donald Hiss as Assistant Managing Editor. The NEWS-LETTER
takes great pleasure in announcing the election of George E.
Banks, Jr., as Assistant Managing Editor.

PRESIDENT GOODNOW
TO RETIRE IN 1929
Mr. Willard Read Announcement
at Committee Meeting Last
Monday
(Continued from page 1, column 5)

"I am going to have some fun."
He furthermore stated that he will
not return to China; his plans for
traveling have not been formulated,
and cannot be made until he knows
at what date he will be relieved by
his successor. As for writing,
President Goodnow does not apparently intend to publish any books
after his retirement.
That Dr. Goodnow will not continue to be connected with the University in any capacity, except possibly that of President Emeritus, is
an established fact. Dr. Goodnow's
predecessor, the late Ira Remsen,
held that office for fourteen years
after his retirement in 1913.
In his letter to Mr. Willard Dr.
Goodnow asked that he be relieved
on or before July 1, 1929, or as
soon as a successor can be secured.
The text of the letter is as follows:
Daniel Willard, Esq.,
President of the Board of
Trustees, the Johns
Hopkins University.
My Dear Mr. Willard—On
January 18, 1929, I shall, if
I live, have attained the age
of 70. I think, in view of
this fact, I should, not later
than July 1, 1929, be relieved
of my duties as president of
the university.
I am therefore handing to
you in this fetter my resignation, to go into effect not later
than July 1, 1929, in order that
you and the trustees may have
ample time in which to select
my successor. Inasmuch as
you may be able to find some
one prior to the date mentioned whom you might wish
to call immediately, will you
please regard this letter as requesting you to accept my
resignation at any time prior
to July 1, 1929, which might
seem to you desirable.
I am handing you my resignation with great regret and
only because it seems to me
that the time has come for me
to do so. My life at the university has been most pleasant
and my relations with the
board could not have been
more agreeable than they have
been.
My good wishes will always
go out to the university and I
shall always look with interest
upon the progress which I am
certain it will make.
I am with the highest personal regards to you and the
other members of the board,
Yours, most sincerely,
FRANK J. GOODNOW.
Mr. Willard, Dean Ames and Dr.
Goodnow, himself, do not know at
present who the latter's successor
will be. It is expected that the
matter will be turned over to a committee of the Board of Trustees on
February 23. The committee will
hold sessions, travel, meet again and
discuss plans, and consume a considerable amount of time before any
decision is reached. It is almost
certain that by next October no selection will yet have been made.
Blow to University

President Goodnow's resignation,
long expected though it may have
been, fills his University associates
with chagrin. Mr. Willard said
Wednesday:
"I regret exceedingly that Dr.
Goodnow considers it expedient to
retire from the Presidency of Johns
Hopkins."

DR. GOODNOW HAS ACHIEVED MUCH
BOTH AT HOPKINS AND ELSEWHERE
Since Dr. Frank J. Goodnow became President of Johns Hopkins
on October 1, 1914, this University
has taken many important forward
steps. Just a year after President
Goodnow's assumption of his duties, the University moved to its
present location at Homewood—a
change which opened many opportunities to students who had not had
sufficient room for their work or
could not before be accommodated
at all.
During the years of stress attendant upon the World War, it was
under Dr. Goodnow's leadership
that the University's activities were
adapted to the necessities of wartime. Following the Armistice the
University experienced the most
rapid growth in its history.
Dormitory and Remsen Hall

New plans were set on foot, and
the years 1923 and 1924 witnessed
the completion of the Alumni Memorial Dormitory and of Remsen
Hall, the first buildings erected
since the transfer to Homewood.
Meanwhile Dr. Goodnow supervised the constant improvement of
the faculty and the continued
growth of the Medical School.
But the greatest achievements of
President Goodnow's term have
been the New, Plan and the HalfCentury CommemOration. To mention both in the same breath is perhaps to slight the former. It was
the President's idea to bring Johns
Hopkins back to the unrivaled reputation as an institution for research
and for the discovery of new truth
which it had held under Dr. Gilman. During the period of rapid

One cannot consider Dr. Goodnow's achievements here without
turning to his record before the
Trustees asked him to become the
head of the University. He took
the degrees of Bachelor and Master
of Arts at Amherst in 1879 and
1887, respectively; he studied also
at Columbia University, where he
teceived the LL.B degree; at the
Ecoles Libres des Sciences Politiques, in Paris, and at the University of Berlin. At Columbia, also,
he held successively the positions
of instructor and lecturer, adjutant
professor and professor of administrative law; in 1903 he was appointed Eaton Professor of Administrative law and municipal science;
during 1906-07 Dr. Goodnow was
acting dean of political science.
Legal Adviser to Chinese

Dr. Goodnow came into still
greater prominence, however, as
legal adviser to the Chinese Government, March 13, 1913-14. From
this post he came to Baltimore to
take over his duties as President.
He is still a member of the China
Medical Board (Rockefeller Foundation), and a fellow of the American Academy of Arts and Sciences.
President Goodnow has received
LL.D degrees from Amherst, Columbia, Harvard, Brown and
Princeton.

He discharged his duties in these
capacities so well that he was given
a mention for valuable services by
the Government. Later he was appointed associate secretary of the
war committee of the Cabinet.
After the war he became director
of the Government Repatriation

1925 he was appointed a Minister
of the Privy Council without portfolio, in which capacity he served
the Canadian Government until his
appointment by the King of England as Canadian Envoy Extraordinary to the United States.

INTERCOLLEGIATE
NEWS
A sweeping athletic reorganization is at present under way at
Syracuse University. Many reforms have been adopted in an attempt to encourage as many students as possible to participate in
some form of athletic activity or
sporting endeavor, and to incidentally decrease the past expenses and
losses which the athletic association
has experienced in past years. Boxing, wrestling, fencing, tennis,
hockey, golf, soccer and rifle are
the sports which have been dropped
from the roster. Football, basketball, rowing, cross-country, lacrosse,
swimming and water polo are the
only activities which have been considered as worthy of retention. This
Plan was originally intended to have
gone into effect at the beginning of
this scholastic year but, because
of a definite outburst of sentiment
among the student body, the plan
was placed under reconsideration
by the athletic council, who recently
repassed it.
As a fact which may be-of interest to sport followers and especially
grid enthusiasts, it has been computed that out of the seventy-one
football captains who have been
selected to head their teams for next
year, forty-five, or over two-thirds
of the total, are linesmen,' while
only the remaining twenty-six are
backfield players. The days when
it was. customary for the quarterback to be the leader appear to have
vanished. Four colleges, Vermont,
Vebarska, Indiana and Iowa, State,
have dual captaincies.
We are informed by an exchange
that Harvard University is considering doing away with all initiations
on the grounds that they are too
childish and are out _of keeping with
the dignity of the institution.
It is rumored that in accordance
with the football reforms which
were proposed last year by the
President of Dartmouth University,
the University of Michigan will
Place two teams on tlre field next
season. An endeavor is being made
to schedule sixteen games, two to
be played on each Saturday of the
1928 campaign, at least one of
which will be played away from
home. This action is said to be a
result of the recent Big Ten conference, which passed a resolution permitting every member to card two
games each Saturday and excepting
them from the former home and
home scrimmage regulation.
* * * * *
Oxford and Cambridge universities are said to be planning a new
form of intercollegiate competition.
The two institutions are arranging
flying contests, which will take place
annually. Each school at present
has its own air squadron.
* * * * *
With the first season of the Air
College declared a success, the College of the City of New York has
opened the second semester over its
radio station. The lectures are
given by various members of the
faculty in an attempt to popularize
education.

THE JOHNS HOPKINS NEWS-LETTER, JANUARY 13, 1928

6

JAY CAGERS BEAT
LOYOLA IN OPENER
Hopkins Team Surprises By
Winning, 26-23
Displaying a brand of basketball
and teamwork that could be appreciated only by a witness, the Johns
Hopkins cagers defeated the Loyola
College five in a hotly contested setto, by the score of 26-23.
In the game, which was not won
until the last thirty seconds of play,
Hopkins made a spectacular review
by outplaying the Irishmen in every
phase of the game. Loyola was
handicapped by the clever work of
Debuskey, Hopkins center, who outjumped his opponent in every start.
Incidentally, the Black and Blue
pivot man contributed more to the
final count than did any of his
mates, accounting for six tallies and
playing a wonderful floor game.
The rare work of the team as a
unit, however, is shown by the fact
that each man tallied at least three
points.
Dudley High Scorer

Captain Frank Dudley, high
scorer for the Green and Gray, was
undoubtedly the star of the contest.
In spite of his great effort, however, his charges were decisively
outplayed, especially during the first
period. At the half the Jays were
on the long end of a 16-9 score.
Although Loyola tied the score
near the close of the contest, Passerew's shot from the floor dashed
any hopes of the Irish for a victory.

CASUAL CONDUCT OF CAMPUS COUPLES
CAUSES COTILLON CLUB CONCERN
"Something for nothing" is usually mighty hard to get, and it has
been claimed by some bitter souls
that this is particularly true at Hopkins. But, at last a campus organization has blazed the trail; it has
declared that, for once, it will depart from its traditional policy and
give the boys a treat. The benevolent souls who originated this charitable idea are none other than the
members of the Johns Hopkins
Cotillon Club.
In an effort to correct the bad
habits of those naughty "collich"
boys who habitually straggle into
dances when they are nearly over,
this puritanical organization has decided to put a premium on punctuality. The first three couples to
arrive at the Cotillon Club dance tomorrow night may enter scot free.
Verily, "the early bird catches the
worm," but the club still maintains
that "it is better to come late than
not at all." Nevertheless, it is to
be noted that the club's charity ap
inscription, however, does not tell
all. Shuter was a pioneer in the
student activities at Johns Hopkins.
Back in 1897-98 the NEWS-LETTER
was first printed, and Shuter was
its first Business Manager.

extend to the stag line. Come early
and avoid the rush.
The dance will start promptly at
nine and it is expected that Goucher
girlies will benefit especially by the
new arrangement. A number of
ladies have recently been heard
complaining that these innocent
young ladies are kept out after
hours Saturday at Hopkins dances.
If the novel scheme works the parties may start early and end early.
Thus, the girls can get their much
needed beauty sleeps and a few
Hopkins escorts may be able to find
a solution to the problem of how to
do on the weeks' allowance.
